It is not only in the case of real estate transfers that the civil law, based upon a natural feeling for the right, punishes trickery and deception, but also in the sale of slaves every form of deception on the vendor's part is disallowed3 For by the aediles' ruling the vendor is answerable for any deficiency in the slave he sells, for he is supposed to know if his slave is sound, or if he is a runaway, or a thief. The r case of those who have just come into the possession of slaves by inheritance is different.

And no greater curse in life can be found than knavery that wears the mask of wis- dom. Thence come those countless cases in which the expedient seems to conflict with the right. For how few will be found who can refrain from wrong- doing‚ if assured of the power to keep it an absolute secret and to run no risk of punishment!

XVIII. Let us put our principle to the test, if you please, and see if it holds good in those instances in which, perhaps, the world in general finds no wrong; for in this connection we do not need to discuss cut-throats, poisoners, forgers of wills, thieves‚ and embezzlers of public moneys, who should be repressed not by lectures and discussions of philoso- phers, but by chains and prison walls3 but let us study here the conduct of those who have the repu- tation of being honest men.
